author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Shrimp Fried Rice With Yum Yum Sauce and More Weeknight Slam-Dunks
description: Shrimp fried rice on its own is great. But with creamy-ketchupy yum yum sauce? It’s, well, you get it.
content: After last week’s newsletter about the food my children eat (and don’t eat), I got about 10 times the number of emails I usually receive, a vast majority of them from parents saying they felt seen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom
title: Seven Prisoners Die as New York Guard Strikes Cause Widespread Disarray
description: Thousands of corrections officers at dozens of prisons have been protesting working conditions in wildcat strikes across the state.
content: At Adirondack Correctional Facility near the Canadian border, the job of delivering meals to hungry inmates fell suddenly to the prison’s superintendent and its teachers and counselors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: Trump Threatens Columbia With Millions in Cuts Over Antisemitism Claims
description: The university, the administration’s first big target in a campaign to root out what it called harassment on campus, could lose more than $50 million in funding.
content: The Trump administration is threatening to cut tens of millions of dollars in federal funding for Columbia University, making the school the first major target in its effort to root out what it considers antisemitic harassment on college campuses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Kortava
title: Why Putin Can’t Wait to Have McDonald’s Back in Moscow
description: As the Trump administration pushes for renewed business ties with Russia, a new book looks back at the companies that helped prop up illiberalism in the country.
content: ZERO SUM: The Arc of International Business in Russia, by Charles Hecker
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Shaw
title: There Is No Musk Exception in the Constitution
description: Trump is on shaky ground when it comes to the way he has empowered perhaps the most important figure in the new administration.
content: It’s difficult to convey the full magnitude of the legal chaos emanating from the Trump administration. It goes well beyond the violation of individual laws — much of the past month has featured what feels like an assault on the very idea of law as a binding constraint.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: Trump’s New Tariffs Could Strain Collection of Customs Fees
description: Importers will have to make changes to pay new tariffs on goods from Canada, Mexico and China, and government agencies will need more resources to enforce the fees.
content: The sweeping tariffs on Canadian, Mexican and Chinese products that President Trump imposed on Tuesday could strain the system that collects import duties and the government agencies that enforce those fees, trade and legal experts said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Not Time’s Fool: A Rare Version of a Shakespeare Sonnet Is Discovered
description: An Oxford researcher found a rare, handwritten variation of one of Shakespeare’s most famous love poems. About 400 years ago, its meaning might have been very different.
content: If you have already had the good fortune of encountering “Sonnet 116” by William Shakespeare, you were probably at a wedding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: On Second Count, ABC Says Oscar Viewership Increased
description: The network said that after total viewership on Hulu was included in the count, the show attracted 19.7 million people, up from 19.5 million last year.
content: On Monday, ABC said the Oscars audience declined by about 8 percent this year compared with last year, citing Nielsen data. Well, it turns out the awards show did not suffer from an audience decline after all, the network said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump’s Sharp Shift on Ukraine and Russia
description: Readers react to news about Russia and Ukraine. Also: A “horrified” expat and a “saddened” Canadian; the new tariffs; research cuts.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Argentines in Rome Pray for a Pope Who’s One of Their Own
description: The expatriate community is small but shares a special bond with Francis, who has been in the hospital since Feb. 14.
content: On Sunday evening, Mariarosa Cavañas lit a candle in front of a small chapel in the Church of Santa Maria Addolorata — the national church of Argentina in Rome — where a photo of Pope Francis was affixed on a dais next to a prayer for his good health. On the back wall of the chapel sat a small statue of Our Lady of Lujàn, the patron saint of Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay, and a prayer entrusting Francis to her care.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: ‘Such a Charmer!’
description: We’re picking up good vibrations from Hanh Huynh’s crossword.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: Conservatives Hobble Iran’s Moderate President, Stoking a Political Crisis
description: With Iran already wounded economically and diplomatically, hard-liners forced out two top officials and blocked talks with the United States, freezing President Masoud Pezeshkian’s agenda.
content: Iran’s conservatives have ousted two high-profile officials, throwing President Masoud Pezeshkian’s new, moderate government into turmoil and raising questions about its survival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
title: Hegseth’s Plans to Reshape the Military Start With Cuts
description: At the same time, Republican lawmakers are aiming to add more than $100 billion to the Pentagon’s proposed budget, which would push military spending close to $1 trillion a year.
content: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth is rushing to reshape the military, in part by shifting money and making cuts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: Is It Time to Transfer Frozen Russian Assets to Ukraine? Calls Grow Louder.
description: President Trump’s threat to abandon Ukraine added urgency to plans to fund security or reconstruction with the roughly $300 billion owned by Russia’s central bank.
content: President Trump’s rancorous threat to abandon Ukraine is stoking support for a long-debated proposal to use billions of dollars in frozen Russian assets to buy weapons for Ukraine and finance its reconstruction.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Drones Define a Deadlier Phase of Ukraine’s War
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, March 4, 2025.
content: “The war is a mix of World War I and World War III — what could be a future war.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Barker
title: The Wi-Fi Code Is ‘TrumpLovesYou,’ but the Cafe’s Clients Aren’t Feeling It
description: At a pizza and coffee joint in Kyiv named for the U.S. president, patrons are having second thoughts about its moniker after President Trump suspended military aid to Ukraine.
content: At the Trump Pizza Station in Kyiv, where the internet password is “TrumpLovesYou,” one woman burst into tears when she learned that the United States was suspending military aid to Ukraine. Another sipped a cappuccino with banana milk and lamented that the whole world seemed to be abandoning her country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman
title: Target Tries to Put a Tough Year Behind It, but Tariffs Loom
description: The retailer ended 2024 with a good holiday season, but warned of uncertainty ahead.
content: Target had a tough 2024: Its stock price declined, it struggled to deliver consistent sales growth, and it faced lawsuits related to its diversity, equity and inclusion practices and then calls for boycotts when it abandoned them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman, Claire Brown and Charlie Savage
title: Climate Groups Were Counting on $20 Billion. Trump Won’t Let Them Access It.
description: The Justice Department and F.B.I. are investigating $20 billion in climate funds, despite a top prosecutor’s decision that there was not sufficient evidence of wrongdoing.
content: Two weeks after their bank accounts were frozen amid a swirl of investigations by the Trump administration, nonprofit organizations that were supposed to receive $20 billion to help curb climate change are still unable to withdraw money, raising concerns about their ability to pay staff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Piglets Left to Die in Art Exhibition Are Stolen in Denmark
description: Three starving piglets were taken from a former butcher’s warehouse, according to the Copenhagen police. The artist said he wanted to wake up society about animal mistreatment.
content: Three piglets were stolen from an art exhibition in Copenhagen over the weekend after a provocative artist said they would be allowed to starve to death in a commentary about animal welfare in Denmark, one of the world’s largest pork exporters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer, Natalie Kitroeff and Maggie Haberman
title: Mexico Gave Trump Much of What He Wanted. It Didn’t Fend Off Tariffs.
description: President Claudia Sheinbaum of Mexico took steps sought by President Trump, including sending troops to the border and cracking down on drug cartels. The tariffs went into effect anyway.
content: Facing the threat of tariffs from President Trump after he took office, Mexico bent over backward to comply with his demands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Van Syckle
title: 5 Takeaways From ‘With Love, Meghan’
description: The new streaming series from the Duchess of Sussex has arrived. It shows her cooking, creating and harvesting, and feels like a billboard for things to come.
content: Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, has returned to the small screen with a new cooking and lifestyle show that was released on Netflix on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: ‘Moby-Dick,’ the Opera, Cuts the Blubber
description: Streamlining Melville’s sprawling novel, Jake Heggie and Gene Scheer’s moody, monochromatic 2010 adaptation has come to the Metropolitan Opera.
content: The opening line of Herman Melville’s “Moby-Dick” is one of the most famous in literature. But Jake Heggie and Gene Scheer, whose moody, monochromatic 2010 adaptation arrived at the Metropolitan Opera on Monday, conspicuously avoid placing those classic three words at the start.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark C. O'Flaherty
title: The Shop That Changed What We Wear
description: Agnès b. was fresh, cool and totally Parisian, and it established the model for a raft of accessibly chic Euro labels to come.
content: Paris is a place for revolutions: the sci-fi fantasies of Cardin and Courrèges, Jean Paul Gaultier’s skirts pour homme and the inflated gothic rituals of Rick Owens. All wild, memorable and museum-worthy. But it may be Agnès Troublé who has changed what we wear today, more so than any fierce iconoclast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Almeida
title: Let the Organ Revitalize You
description: No, not that kind of organ.
content: When I lived in Chicago, my wife and I would, whenever we could, see movies at a theater called the Music Box. Opened in 1929, the main auditorium has a ceiling painted to look like the night sky, a red velvet curtain that reveals the screen — and an organ. The organ is hard to miss: a massive brown Kimball console, right up there by the stage, with multiple keyboards and a half ring of red, white, black and yellow stops. Before films on weekends, a spotlight will beam and the house organist will play. On occasion, he will even accompany a silent film.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: A pause on U.S. aid to Ukraine.
content: President Trump suspended the delivery of military aid to Ukraine yesterday, according to senior U.S. officials, who said the pause would stay in effect until Trump determined that Ukraine had demonstrated a good-faith commitment to peace talks with Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: The (Fatuous) Case for Betraying Ukraine
description: The organizing principle of Putin’s reign has been the restoration of Soviet power at the expense of people power.
content: There’s an argument that passes for a sophisticated defense of Donald Trump’s and JD Vance’s beat down of Volodymyr Zelensky in the Oval Office last Friday. Here it is in a nutshell:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Lincoln Díaz-Balart, a ‘Free Cuba’ Republican in Congress, Dies at 70
description: The Florida scion of an anti-communist political family, he served in the House for 18 years at a time when Cuban Americans exerted peak influence on U.S. policies.
content: Lincoln Díaz-Balart, a staunchly anti-communist Florida Republican who helped enshrine into law the U.S. trade embargo against Cuba and who defended immigrants’ rights during his nearly two decades in Congress, died on Monday at his home in Key Biscayne, Fla. He was 70.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: In Face of Trump’s Tariffs, Mexico Embraces Its President and Nationalism
description: Before the tariffs went into effect, approval ratings for President Claudia Sheinbaum rose and companies began marketing “Made in Mexico” products.
content: Claudia Sheinbaum, the president of Mexico, stood underneath a giant Mexican flag and before troops at a military installation in Mexico City. It was Flag Day last month and she used her speech as an opportunity to, figuratively and literally, rally around it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ariana Drehsler
title: In the L.A. Fires, a Photographer Finds a Moment of Stillness
description: A photojournalist was on the ground in Southern California in January to capture the fires’ devastation.
content: I’m a freelance photojournalist and have contributed to The New York Times since 2016. Over the last decade I have documented many scenes for The Times, including homeless encampments in Los Angeles and the people trying to help those who live there; a ghost town near the California-Nevada border in need of revitalization; and the unexpected union between a “kitten lady” and a cat photographer, a “meow” made in heaven.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lukas Hermsmeier
title: Germany Needs to Get Its Act Together. Under Him, It Won’t.
description: Friedrich Merz, almost certain to be the country’s next chancellor, is yesterday’s man.
content: Friedrich Merz didn’t waste time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: Israel Says It Killed Local Hamas Commander in West Bank
description: The raid took place as Israel’s military said it had expanded its operation to crack down on militants in the city of Jenin.
content: The Israeli military said on Tuesday that its forces had killed a Hamas military commander in the city of Jenin in the occupied West Bank as it expanded on a series of raids that have displaced tens of thousands of Palestinians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Oscars Draw 18 Million Viewers, an 8% Drop
description: The show was broadcast on ABC, as it has been for decades, but also streamed live on Hulu, where there were glitches.
content: The Academy Awards drew 18 million viewers on Sunday, ABC said, citing Nielsen data. That is an 8 percent drop from the 19.5 million who watched last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Jay-Z Sues Rape Accuser and Lawyers, Saying They Knew Claim Was False
description: The anonymous woman withdrew her sex abuse suit last month, but the entertainer says in court papers she has since admitted her account was fabricated. She and her lawyer deny that.
content: Jay-Z filed a lawsuit on Monday against the anonymous woman who withdrew her rape lawsuit against him last month, asserting that she and her lawyers knew the allegations were false but proceeded with the claim anyway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Slagle
title: 7 Ways to Make Your Roasted Broccoli Better
description: “Broccoli, again?” just became “broccoli, again!”
content: When home cooks put away the steamer and started cranking their ovens instead, broccoli’s image changed from divisive to divine. Steamed broccoli can be wonderful (if you don’t overcook it to mush), but there’s something especially alluring about the crisp, nutty flowers and sweet, tender stems of roasted broccoli trees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Wild Coast Raw Food for Cats Is Recalled Over Bird Flu Risk
description: At least two cats kept as pets had tested positive for bird flu in two counties in Washington State after their owners reported feeding them the product, officials said.
content: A company in Washington State voluntarily recalled a raw food product for cats this week because of the potential risk that it may have been contaminated with bird flu amid outbreaks in poultry and cows across the United States, federal safety regulators said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: Baby Seal Who Was Rescued From a Busy Connecticut Street Has Died
description: The seal named Chappy, which had been found flat on its stomach on a cold, snow-encrusted street in New Haven, Conn., had an intestinal disease, a necropsy showed.
content: Chappy, the underweight gray seal pup who was found on its stomach on a street in New Haven, Conn., last month, drawing nationwide attention and local police affection, has died, the aquarium that was caring for him announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey A. Sonnenfeld and Stephen Henriques
title: Memo to the Business Elite: It’s Time to Stand Up
description: Most executives are not protectionist, isolationist or xenophobic. Nor do they want to be complicit.
content: The first reactions from chief executives to the second Trump administration were as varied as the companies they run. Some liked the promises of federal spending cuts, deregulation and a revamped trade agenda. Others worried about the direct costs of tariffs on their industries and signs of falling consumer confidence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Much-Needed Storage Space That Hides in Plain Sight
description: Designers can tuck storage into the furniture, behind the walls, along hallways and into awkward spaces.
content: Having convenient, well-organized places to store things can help make life at home feel a little more peaceful. That’s why so many architects and interior designers are almost obsessive about maximizing opportunities to eke out more storage space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Republican House Members Told to Stop Holding In-Person Town Halls
description: The chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee told G.O.P. lawmakers that public confrontations with angry constituents could hurt them politically in the midterm elections.
content: Representative Richard Hudson of North Carolina, the chairman of House Republicans’ campaign arm, issued a stark message to the G.O.P. rank and file on Tuesday: Stop having in-person town halls with your constituents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: Peter Sichel, Wine Merchant With a Cloak-and-Dagger Past, Dies at 102
description: He played a crucial role in the early days of the C.I.A., as a station chief in Cold War Berlin and Hong Kong, before shifting gears to popularize Blue Nun wine.
content: Refugee, prisoner, wine merchant, spy: Peter Sichel was many things in his long, colorful life, but he was probably most often identified as the man who made Blue Nun one of the most popular wines in the world in the 1970s and ’80s. At its peak, in 1985, 30 million bottles of this slightly sweet German white wine — its label featuring smiling nuns holding baskets of grapes in a vineyard — were sold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Jentleson
title: To Oppose Trump, Democrats Should Remember How They Opposed George W. Bush
description: What the left chooses to fight on now will shape future elections.
content: President Trump is misreading his mandate. He ran on lowering the cost of living, but the price of eggs is going up, and he is plotting to increase health care premiums. He disavowed Project 2025 but seems to be fulfilling it page by page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Biden’s Envoy to Fight Antisemitism Says She Saw Surge of Hate After Oct. 7
description: Reflecting at the end of her tenure, Deborah Lipstadt said that after the Hamas-led attack on Israel and the devastating war in Gaza, antisemitism became “almost normalized.”
content: When Deborah Lipstadt was appointed the Biden administration’s special envoy to fight antisemitism abroad, she started by visiting Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates for what she described as encouraging exchanges with leaders of the two Muslim nations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Lawsuit Over Zelle Scams Is Dropped by Consumer Bureau
description: A spokeswoman for the payment app’s parent company said the lawsuit against three large banks was “without merit, and legally and factually flawed.”
content: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau on Tuesday dismissed a sweeping lawsuit against three of the nation’s largest banks over what the agency had described as shoddy safeguards on their Zelle money transfer network that allowed scammers to steal hundreds of millions of dollars from customers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: 2 Democrats Begin Investigation of Move to Drop Adams Charges
description: In a letter to Attorney General Pam Bondi, the lawmakers, Jamie Raskin of Maryland and Jasmine Crockett of Texas, accused the Justice Department of a coverup.
content: Two top Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee have begun an investigation into the Justice Department’s request to drop federal criminal charges against Mayor Eric Adams of New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark O'Connell
title: What if Your Dreams Could Land You in Prison?
description: In Laila Lalami’s new novel, a woman finds herself trapped in a nightmarish system of surveillance and detention.
content: “The Dream Hotel,” the fifth novel by the acclaimed Moroccan American writer Laila Lalami, is set in a near-future reality only a notch or two on the dystopian dial away from our present. Its protagonist, Sara Hussein, is a museum archivist in her late 30s, living in Los Angeles with her husband, Elias, and their toddler twins. As a new mother suffering the rigors of insomnia, she finds relief in something called a Dreamsaver, an ingenious neuroprosthetic device that ensures high-quality sleep. Embedded in the device’s terms of service, however, is a clause allowing the extraction and sale of its users’ biometrical data, including the content of their dreams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes and Cassandra Vinograd
title: Why Is Trump Pausing Aid to Ukraine? What to Know.
description: The decision marked the realization of a fear that has racked Ukraine since President Trump’s re-election.
content: The Trump administration’s decision to suspend the delivery of all military assistance to Ukraine left Ukrainians and Europeans figuring out on Tuesday how to fend for themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson, Ian Austen and Simon Romero
title: Trump’s Tariffs on Canada, Mexico and China Snap Into Effect
description: President Trump imposed hefty tariffs on the United States’ largest trading partners on Tuesday, roiling global relations and sending shock waves through industries that depend on trade.
content: Sweeping tariffs on imports from Canada, Mexico and China went into effect just after midnight on Tuesday, raising U.S. tariffs to levels not seen in decades and rattling foreign governments and businesses that depend on international trade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Conor Dougherty
title: After the Apocalypse, Will We Decamp to a Suburb or a High-Rise?
description: “Paradise” and “Silo” have opposing takes on the future of urban organization, echoing the debate over America’s housing shortage today.
content: “Paradise” is a TV show on Hulu about a postapocalyptic society that lives underground in a suburb. “Silo” is a TV show on Apple TV+ about a postapocalyptic society that lives underground in an apartment tower.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: A Russia-Friendly Region Cheers Trump’s Reordering of the U.S. Role in the World
description: Many ethnic Serbs in what was once Yugoslavia have long chafed at Washington’s foreign policy. ‘Trump’s America is different,’ said a former leader of a Serb enclave in Bosnia.
content: As the United States and Europe condemned Russia for its invasion of Ukraine, Sasa Bozic responded by opening the Putin Café in the Bosnian city of Banja Luka, decorating it with a mannequin of the Russian president — a foot taller than Vladimir V. Putin is in real life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Democrats Call for Inquiry Into Top Justice Official Over Adams Case
description: Senate Democrats asked a New York legal disciplinary panel to consider whether Emil Bove III abused his power in seeking the dismissal of the federal corruption case against Mayor Eric Adams.
content: Senate Democrats on Tuesday asked a New York committee that disciplines lawyers to investigate whether the acting deputy attorney general violated rules of professional conduct by demanding that prosecutors abandon a corruption case against Mayor Eric Adams of New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: For Once, Good News About the B.Q.E.
description: Fewer overweight trucks are heading toward Queens, the Department of Transportation found, thanks to hidden sensors.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll get an update on sensors that can tell when trucks on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway are overweight. We’ll also get details on a guilty plea by a teacher at a Brooklyn prep school who was accused of soliciting lewd photos and videos from students on Snapchat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Where Being Gay Is Punishable by Death, Aid Cuts Are ‘Heartbreaking’
description: Uganda’s L.G.B.T.Q. population was already struggling to cope with the fallout of a harsh anti-gay law when the disruption of U.S. aid put people at even greater risk.
content: In the weeks since President Trump signed an executive order dismantling the U.S. Agency for International Development, Andrea Minaj Casablanca’s phone has been inundated with desperate pleas for help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Vance Ignites Outrage in Britain With ‘Random Country’ Comment
description: The vice president denied that he was talking about Britain and France when he downplayed “20,000 troops from some random country” protecting Ukraine. No other countries have pledged troops.
content: Vice President JD Vance has sparked a storm of criticism in Britain after declaring that an American economic deal in Ukraine was a “better security guarantee than 20,000 troops from some random country that hasn’t fought a war in 30 or 40 years.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Peyser
title: Dr. Pimple Popper Knows You Can’t Look Away
description: Dr. Sandra Lee has built a new kind of dermatologic empire by sharing gnarly extractions and cyst removals with the world online.
content: Dr. Sandra Lee has seen it all, dermatologically speaking. A cyst as big as a grapefruit. A blackhead so large it looked like a worn penny. A benign fatty mass sticking out of a neck like a second head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Higginbotham
title: Indigenous Australian Art Takes Center Stage at TEFAF Maastricht
description: This year’s fair will include a booth dedicated solely to First Nations Australian art, from bark paintings to works by Emily Kam Kngwarray.
content: In a first for TEFAF Maastricht, visitors to this year’s fair will encounter a booth dedicated entirely to Australia’s First Nations art. The show is set to feature over a dozen artists, working from the 1960s to present day, providing a broad picture of the contemporary Indigenous Australian art movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle and Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Deals Blow to E.P.A. in Dispute Over Federal Water Rules
description: The 5-to-4 decision is the latest setback for the agency and could have sweeping implications for curtailing water pollution offshore.
content: The Supreme Court sided with San Francisco on Tuesday in a challenge to water quality regulations issued by the Environmental Protection Agency in a ruling that could have sweeping implications for the agency’s ability to limit offshore pollution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caroline Hopkins Legaspi
title: My Partner Snores. Are There Any Tricks to Get Some Sleep?
description: A pillow over the ear may not be enough. Here’s what might help.
content: Q: I love my partner, but the rumbling snores keep me awake. Are there solutions for people like us?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward
title: Israel Strikes Syria Again as Tensions Rise
description: The latest attacks came a week after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel demanded the demilitarization of much of southern Syria, stoking fears of conflict with the country’s new leadership.
content: Israel has conducted new airstrikes on Syria’s coast and ground raids in the country’s south, part of a recent wave of attacks that Israel says are necessary for its security and that have raised tensions with Syria’s new government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: Supreme Court Appears Skeptical of Mexico’s Lawsuit Against U.S. Gun Makers
description: A majority of the justices seemed to question Mexico’s claim that it could prove a direct chain linking arms manufacturers to drug cartel violence.
content: The Supreme Court appeared skeptical on Tuesday that the Mexican government could legally sue U.S. gun makers over claims that they share the blame for violence by drug cartels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Recaps Zelensky’s Casual Friday at the White House
description: “I don’t see you asking Elon Musk if he owns a suit,” Seth Meyers said of the reporter who questioned Ukraine’s president about his attire.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and Ana Swanson
title: Trump’s Trade War Could Be His Biggest Economic Gamble
description: President Trump has offered a mix of reasons for upending global trade relations, baffling and angering America’s biggest trading partners.
content: President Trump made one of the biggest gambles of his presidency Tuesday by initiating sweeping tariffs with no clear rationale on imports from Canada, Mexico and China, triggering a trade war that risks undermining the United States economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: World’s Largest Iceberg Runs Aground
description: A massive superberg, four times as big as New York City, has halted east of the southern tip of South America.
content: After months of drifting, the world’s largest iceberg has come to a halt near the island of South Georgia in the South Atlantic Ocean.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: What to Expect From Trump’s Address to Congress
description: Also, Canada and China retaliated against U.S. tariffs. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: President Trump goes to the Capitol this evening for his first address to a joint session of Congress since his return to the White House in January. The speech will offer him his most prominent platform so far to promote his sweeping transformation of the federal government and lay out his vision for the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman and Brad Plumer
title: U.S. State Department Shuts Down Pollution Monitoring Abroad
description: Since 2008, embassies and other diplomatic posts had been publishing data about local air quality. In many countries, it was the only reliable source of such information.
content: What’s the air quality in New Delhi, Jakarta or Buenos Aires? Until Tuesday, the United States Embassy in those cities could have told you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Pager
title: Here’s What to Watch For in Trump’s Speech to Congress
description: Presidents typically use these speeches to promote their accomplishments and lay out their plans. President Trump is expected to touch on Ukraine and government cuts.
content: Since taking office just six weeks ago, President Trump has blitzed Washington by issuing a flurry of executive actions and leading a dramatic overhaul of the federal bureaucracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Weed
title: See Spot Spa: Hotels Are Ready to Pamper Your Pup
description: A growing number of Americans are traveling with pets, and many are staying in places that offer their dogs amenities like robes, fresh meals and wilderness hikes.
content: The first time Benji, a 5-year-old Maltese mix, checked into the NH Collection New York Madison Avenue with her owner, something seemed a bit off: The metal food and water bowls just would not do. So the staff scrambled, offering the little dog 10 different options until she found a porcelain one she liked. And now that she’s a frequent guest, they store that bowl for her next visit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Edmund Lee
title: Trump’s Tariffs Plunge Global Markets Into a Sea of Red
description: Global leaders are retaliating and investors have sold off stocks in Asia and Europe.
content: President Trump wasn’t bluffing, after all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green, Eric Schmitt, David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
title: Trump Suspends Military Aid to Ukraine After Oval Office Blowup
description: The directive, which takes effect immediately, affects more than $1 billion in arms and ammunition in the pipelines and on order.
content: President Trump on Monday temporarily suspended the delivery of all U.S. military aid to Ukraine, senior administration and military officials said, just days after Mr. Trump and President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine had an explosive confrontation at the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross and Christine Hauser
title: Storm Kills 3 in Mississippi and 2 in Nebraska Before Moving East
description: The storm was forecast to bring thunderstorms and damaging winds to the East Coast on Wednesday.
content: A severe storm was moving east across the central and southern United States on Wednesday, a day after it carved a destructive path that killed three people in Mississippi and two in Nebraska, pulled down power lines and ripped roofs off buildings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Karaian
title: Companies in Europe Face Squeeze in U.S.-China Trade War
description: Some European executives see rising trade tensions as a potential opportunity, but they are watching warily for more moves in Washington.
content: Europe was not directly targeted in the wave of U.S. tariffs that took effect on Tuesday, but the effects are being felt here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Ismaeel Naar
title: Arab States Propose Alternative to Trump’s Gaza Plan
description: Trying to counter President Trump’s call to “clean out” Gaza, Arab leaders have begun to outline their own vision for Palestinians in the territory.
content: Arab countries countered President Trump’s proposal to expel Palestinians from Gaza and transform it into a beachfront destination with their own vision on Tuesday, endorsing a plan to keep the population there, rebuild the territory and turn it into part of a future Palestinian state, without Hamas in government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Connections Companion No. 633
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, March 5, 2025.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: The Government Knows A.G.I. Is Coming
description: The Biden administration’s A.I. adviser Ben Buchanan discusses how the U.S. government is preparing for artificial general intelligence — and all the challenges that remain.
content: This is an edited transcript of an episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.” You can listen to the conversation by following or subscribing to the show on the NYT Audio App, Apple, Spotify, Amazon Music, YouTube, iHeartRadio or wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Michael D. Shear
title: In Speech to Congress, Trump Is Expected to Boast About DOGE Cuts and Ukraine
description: Tuesday night’s address will be a remarkable return to a chamber that President Trump last addressed five years ago, before voters ousted him from office.
content: President Trump is expected to boast about his assault on the federal bureaucracy and his efforts to upend global relationships during an address to a joint session of Congress on Tuesday, even as his administration faces lawsuits over his domestic agenda and Europe rebukes him over his treatment of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Abrams, David A. Fahrenthold, Anna Foley, Olivia Natt, Mary Wilson, Carlos Prieto, M.J. Davis Lin, Patricia Willens, Pat McCusker, Rowan Niemisto and Alyssa Moxley
title: DOGE Has a Math Problem
description: Why the claims of Elon Musk’s government-cutting team are not what they seem.
content: Since President Trump took office, Elon Musk and DOGE have wielded an unprecedented level of power to help the administration cut the U.S. government, and they claim to have stopped tens of billions of dollars in wasteful spending.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: In One Swing District, Guarded Optimism After Trump’s First Six Weeks
description: With President Trump set to address a joint session of Congress on Tuesday, many voters in Arizona’s divided First Congressional District remain hopeful for his new term, even amid partisan rancor.
content: Keith Mann, a self-described independent voter, sat out the 2024 election, dismayed by both candidates for president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: America vs. The World: Trump Shows How Far He Is Willing to Take ‘America First.’
description: President Trump has frayed alliances across the globe with his words and actions.
content: On the campaign trail, President Trump made no secret about how he would approach a second term: He would get tough with nations around the world, even friends and allies, that he believed were taking advantage of the United States’ economic and military might.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: China Targets San Diego Biotech Firm in Broadening Blacklist
description: In a sign it is willing to go further in responding to President Trump’s tariffs, Beijing blocked more American companies from importing goods into China.
content: China signaled on Tuesday that it is willing to go further than before in its trade tit-for-tat with President Trump by hitting a top American biotechnology company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Emily Kask
title: Mardi Gras 2025: Joy and Jitters for New Orleans
description: There was never any question that Mardi Gras would go forward after the New Year’s Day terror attack in New Orleans. But some revelers felt at least a hint of trepidation.
content: The plans had been set for months: Dr. Roquell E. Wyche would finally take her son, Jaxon, to New Orleans, joining nearly 40 members of her husband’s family for their annual celebration of Mardi Gras.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Steven Erlanger
title: Europe Tries to Boost Military Spending as America Realigns
description: The European Commission’s president unveiled a sweeping plan to help Ukraine and boost defense spending, but it won’t be easy.
content: A top European official on Tuesday laid out a sweeping framework aimed at rearming the continent, trying to fill a void as President Trump retreated from supporting Ukraine and pressured Europe to spend more on its own defense.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: He Fought Claims of Harm From Infant Formula. Now He Regulates It.
description: Kyle Diamantas, a former corporate lawyer, is the new director for the F.D.A. food division, which oversees infant formula. He defended a top maker in cases claiming the company had not warned of potential risks to very low-weight babies.
content: The new head of the Food and Drug Administration division that regulates infant formula was in recent months a corporate lawyer defending a top formula maker from claims that its product gave rise to debilitating harm to premature babies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Olivier Awards: ‘Fiddler on the Roof’ Secures Most Nominations
description: The acclaimed revival, which is about to transfer to London’s Barbican, scored 13 nominations at Britain’s equivalent of the Tonys.
content: A revival of “Fiddler on the Roof,” the much-loved 1964 musical, received the most nominations on Tuesday for this year’s Olivier Awards, Britain’s equivalent of the Tonys.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ruberg
title: 7 Tesla Charging Stations Torched Near Boston
description: The fires, which the police said were intentionally set, are the latest in a series of attacks against Elon Musk’s company.
content: Seven Tesla charging stations were intentionally set on fire on Monday at a shopping center outside Boston, the police said, the latest in a series of attacks against the electric vehicle company since its owner, Elon Musk, built a deep partnership with President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teddy Rosenbluth
title: As Measles Spreads, Kennedy Embraces Remedies Like Cod Liver Oil
description: In an interview, the H.H.S. secretary claimed that unconventional treatments were helping patients but described vaccination as a personal choice.
content: As a measles outbreak expands in West Texas, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the health and human services secretary, on Tuesday cheered several unconventional treatments, including cod liver oil, but again did not urge all Americans to get vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Brown
title: A Straightforward Climate Fix Hits Another Setback
description: Cutting down emissions of planet-warming methane from oil and gas production was supposed to be relatively simple. It hasn’t worked that way.
content: For the oil and gas industry, cutting emissions of one of the most potent greenhouse gases was supposed to be relatively straightforward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah Weiner
title: The ‘Parasite’ Director Brings Class Warfare To Outer Space
description: Bong Joon Ho has turned his funny-sad excavations of life under capitalism into unlikely blockbusters. With “Mickey 17,” he’s bending a whole new genre.
content: Bong Joon Ho sent a text message a bit past noon, naming a subway station in Seoul and asking me to meet him there at 7 p.m. In his imperfect English, he signed off with a cryptic tease: “I’ll show you some ordinary but strange area. See you in front of GATE No. 4.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gracelin Baskaran
title: How Trump Can Turn the Ukraine Mineral Deal Into Real Security
description: Trump needs to back up any minerals agreement with substantive investment and diplomacy.
content: For many years, while China strategically secured minerals from around the world, the United States rarely used foreign policy to obtain the minerals it needs. That has finally changed — and dramatically so. Within the first 40 days of President Trump’s term, he has expressed interest in acquiring Greenland for its rare earths; annexing Canada, with its vast reserves of uranium and copper; and securing control over Ukraine’s rare earths and titanium in exchange for continued U.S. support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: After a Decade Away, ‘Mamma Mia!’ Is Returning to Broadway This Summer
description: The musical’s original run was the ninth-longest in Broadway history; a six-month return engagement will start in August.
content: “Mamma Mia!” is returning to Broadway this summer after a decade away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Maine Lobster Industry Can Sue Seafood Watchdog for Defamation, Judge Rules
description: A group of fishermen says that it lost business after Seafood Watch, a program run by the Monterey Bay Aquarium, advised consumers not to buy lobster from the state.
content: Maine’s lobster industry can proceed with a defamation lawsuit that it brought against a seafood watchdog group, which had placed a do-not-buy designation on the crustaceans because of the dangers it said that the industry’s fishing nets posed to an endangered whale species.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nazaneen Ghaffar and Judson Jones
title: Sprawling System Brings Warnings for Extreme Weather to Much of the U.S.
description: An “unusually strong” storm system for March may bring a range of hazards that includes wildfires, blizzards and tornadoes.
content: What forecasters are calling an “unusually strong” storm system for this time of year is poised to intensify on Tuesday, bringing warnings for blizzard conditions to the Plains, wildfire weather to Texas, severe storms in the South and strong winds across the Central United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Germans Agree to Borrow More for Military, in Sharp Response to Trump
description: The agreement between Friedrich Merz, the likely next chancellor, and his potential coalition partners also includes big new infrastructure spending.
content: Ever since the Berlin Wall fell and the country reunited, Germans could be expected to keep budget deficits relatively low, military spending even lower, and politics at a plodding pace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edmund Lee
title: Trump’s Crypto Reserve Plan Raises Doubts. Here’s What We Know.
description: The prospect of using taxpayer money to stockpile cryptocurrencies in a national reserve has drawn criticism from lawmakers and investors.
content: The crypto market gives and takes: After President Trump’s plan for a national crypto reserve drew backlash from both Republicans and investors, the prices of digital tokens that would be involved soared higher — and then tumbled. (Bitcoin was trading at about $83,800 early on Tuesday, down nearly $10,000 from a day ago.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Trudeau, on His Way Out of Office, Sharply Rebukes Trump Over Tariffs
description: The Canadian prime minister was visibly angry not only over the president’s tariffs, but also over his repeated suggestions that he would make Canada ‘the 51st state’ and his growing closeness to Russia.
content: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada rebuked President Trump directly on Tuesday over sweeping new tariffs and pledged to “relentlessly” battle to protect his country’s economy. “A fight with Canada will have no winners,” Mr. Trudeau said, just days before he is set to step down as prime minister.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: Stories by Harper Lee to Appear for the First Time in a New Collection
description: Before she published “To Kill a Mockingbird,” Lee had written short stories in which she explored some of its themes and characters.
content: For years before she published “To Kill a Mockingbird,” Harper Lee wrote short stories with themes that she would later explore in that now-classic novel: small town gossip and politics, tender and tense relationships between fathers and daughters, race relations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Minho Kim
title: Here’s How to Watch Trump’s Address to Congress
description: At 9 p.m. Eastern, President Trump will speak to a joint session of Congress for the first time in his second term. The New York Times will carry the address live.
content: President Trump will address the joint session of Congress on Tuesday night at 9 p.m., expected to lay out his aggressive agenda for remaking the federal government and shifting U.S. foreign policy during his first televised prime-time speech of his second term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: ‘Trump Is the Real Thing’
description: Vengeance is his.
content: With Donald Trump back in the White House, each new week produces an onslaught of radical policy initiatives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: Mexican Leader Pledges Retaliation Soon if Trump’s Tariffs Remain in Place
description: President Claudia Sheinbaum roundly criticized the U.S. tariffs on Mexico and said retaliatory measures would be announced Sunday if they were still in effect.
content: President Claudia Sheinbaum of Mexico kept her silence overnight. But on Tuesday morning, she kicked off her daily news conference with a sharply-worded statement in which she said her government rejected President Donald Trump’s characterization of Mexico, and she roundly criticized the 25 percent tariffs that he imposed on it hours earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura van den Berg
title: Inside a Sadistic Sisterhood at the End of the World
description: In Agustina Bazterrica’s new novel, “The Unworthy,” a dystopian future ravaged by climate change has stripped the world of food, water and human connection.
content: Writers have long been preoccupied with the end of the world, though perhaps it would be more accurate to say that the true preoccupation is with whatever new, tenuous social order struggles up from the rubble. What would starting over look like? And are human beings doomed to create dystopian conditions wherever they go?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: My Favorite Concerts I Saw This Winter
description: Hear music from Father John Misty, Mustafa and other artists our critic caught onstage so far this year.
content: Even during this long, often bitterly cold winter, I sometimes made it out of my apartment — please clap — to see live music. To commemorate this monumental human achievement, today I’m offering you a playlist of some of the best artists I’ve caught onstage so far this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Zelensky Offers Terms to Stop Fighting, Assuring U.S. That Ukraine Wants Peace
description: “We are working on all possible scenarios to protect Ukraine,” said President Volodymyr Zelensky, whose country was looking to European allies for support.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine on Tuesday offered a course of action that he said could end the war, while trying to assure the Trump administration that his government was dedicated to peace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Gallagher
title: It’s Hard to Believe How Cool These Dresses Are
description: Illuminated, kaleidoscopic dresses at Anrealage made the case that we’re all walking billboards.
content: What’s the difference between a gimmick and a good idea? One makes you grimace, the other makes you grin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Democrats Block Bill to Bar Transgender Girls From Female Sports Teams
description: Republicans argued the bill was essential to protecting women and girls, but also made clear they were bringing it up to portray Democrats as outside the mainstream. It stalled in the Senate.
content: Democrats on Monday blocked a Republican-written bill aimed at barring transgender women and girls from school sports teams designated for female students, thwarting consideration in the Senate of the G.O.P.’s latest move to use transgender people as leverage at the dawn of President Trump’s second term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Wednesday Briefing: Canada and China Strike Back at Tariffs
description: Plus, a top architecture award for Liu Jiakun.
content: Canada and China yesterday condemned the sweeping tariffs imposed by the Trump administration and said they would retaliate against U.S. exports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: nomenclature
description: This word has appeared in 23 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word nomenclature has appeared in 23 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 19 in “The Year Country Went Everywhere, and Everyone Went Country” by Jon Caramanica. The article discusses Beyoncé’s “Cowboy Carter” album:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Is It Ever OK For Parents to Lie to Their Children?
description: Should parents shield their children from painful truths with white lies? Or is it always better to level with them about difficult realities?
content: Have your parents ever lied to you?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: U.S. Attorney Rebuffed by Justice Dept. in Push to Escalate Inquiry Into Schumer
description: Ed Martin, the acting U.S. attorney in Washington, has been blocked so far in seeking a grand jury investigation into remarks made by Senator Chuck Schumer about Supreme Court justices.
content: Ed Martin, the interim U.S. attorney for the District of Columbia, has been quietly pushing to present evidence against Senator Charles Schumer of New York, the Democratic leader, to a federal grand jury over comments he made about Supreme Court justices in 2020, according to people with knowledge of the situation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Arlo Brown
title: Why Composers Want to Write Operas for Children
description: This genre allows artists to tap into their inner child. But it’s absolutely serious work.
content: A lonely schoolboy named Bertil makes a magical friend who goes by Nils in “Nils Karlsson Däumling,” a children’s opera by Thierry Tidrow based on a fairy tale by Astrid Lindgren. Nils teaches Bertil to change his size by singing a spell-like song.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: In Oct. 7 Report, Israeli Security Agency Puts Some Blame on Netanyahu Government
description: The Shin Bet said that it had disregarded intelligence from Gaza about a planned Hamas raid, but also that government policies may have emboldened the militants to attack.
content: Israel’s domestic security service on Tuesday assumed responsibility for failing to heed warning signs of a planned Hamas attack before the militants’ devastating strike on Oct. 7, 2023. But the agency also faulted the Israeli government for policies it said had allowed Hamas to quietly amass weapons, collect funds and gain support, among other failures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Kaye
title: American Farmers Brace for Harm From Retaliatory Tariffs
description: Trade wars during President Trump’s first term slashed billions of dollars in U.S. agricultural exports. Farmers and trade groups expect an even bigger hit this time.
content: A trade war with China during President Trump’s first term hit American farmers hard. This time, it could be worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: How Dolly Parton’s Husband, Carl Dean, Inspired ‘Jolene’
description: She wrote the hit 1973 song after a bank teller caught the eye of Dean, who died on Monday. She attributed its success to its simplicity and the universal emotions it evokes.
content: In the early years of her nearly six-decade marriage, Dolly Parton noticed that her husband was spending a lot of time at the bank, where he had developed a crush on a teller. She told him to knock it off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Chris Jasper, Who Helped Revitalize the Isley Brothers, Dies at 73
description: A classically trained pianist turned songwriter, he was a cornerstone of the soul group’s sound during its fertile second act in the 1970s.
content: Chris Jasper, a Juilliard-trained keyboardist, singer and songwriter who brought an expansive musical vocabulary to the long-running R&B group the Isley Brothers, helping push them into a new hit-making era in the 1970s and ’80s with singles like “That Lady” and “Fight the Power,” died on Feb. 23. He was 73.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Judge Says Trump Can’t Fire Chair of Federal Workers Board Without Cause
description: Cathy Harris had sued to block her dismissal from the panel that handles government employee disputes. Employees swept up in the Trump administration’s mass firings have appealed to the board.
content: A federal judge on Tuesday blocked the Trump administration from firing Cathy Harris, the chair of an independent board that protects government workers from political discrimination and unfair labor practices, including wrongful termination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Trump Administration Said to Drop Lawsuit Over Toxic Chemical
description: The Biden administration had sued to force the Denka Performance Elastomer plant in Louisiana to reduce emissions of chloroprene, a likely carcinogen.
content: The Trump administration plans to drop a federal lawsuit against a chemical manufacturer accused of releasing high levels of a likely carcinogen from its Louisiana plant, according to two people familiar with the plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simbarashe Cha
title: A Fuzzy Jacket and Rumpled Jeans
description: Each brought different textures to a tactile outfit.
content: With flavors of both a bow tie and a cravat, the ribbed scarf knotted around the neck of Evan Naurais immediately stood out when we crossed paths in Paris on a Saturday in early February. It was a dapper finishing touch to a tactile outfit that also involved a fuzzy, olive green jacket and stylishly rumpled dark jeans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ruberg and Alexandra E. Petri
title: Carl Dean, Dolly Parton’s Husband of Nearly 60 Years, Dies at 82
description: Mr. Dean, who inspired songs including “Jolene” and “From Here to the Moon and Back,” was known to shy away from the spotlight as his wife rose to fame.
content: Carl Dean, an asphalt paver who met his future wife, Dolly Parton, outside a Nashville laundromat more than six decades ago and quietly championed her as she rose to superstardom, died on Monday. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: C.D.C. Sends ‘Disease Detectives’ to Texas for Measles Outbreak
description: The Trump administration is stepping in to help Texas respond to the deadly and highly contagious respiratory virus.
content: The federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has sent some of its “disease detectives” to West Texas to help with the measles outbreak there — a sign that the Trump administration is getting more deeply involved in the response.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland and Jan Hoffman
title: Trump Administration Ties Tariffs to Fatal Fentanyl Overdoses, Which Are Declining
description: The decrease in fentanyl overdoses, drug policy experts have said, has more to do with public health measures than changes in border policies.
content: Howard Lutnick, the U.S. secretary of commerce, said in an interview on Tuesday that the tariffs President Trump imposed on Canada, Mexico and China could be lifted if those countries proved to Mr. Trump that they were stopping the flow of fentanyl and reducing the number of fatal fentanyl overdoses in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Gallaher
title: Showing Courage in Ukraine With Handfuls of Clay
description: Founded seven years ago in Kyiv, GORN Ceramics has become an object lesson in survival.
content: In late August 2020, eight humanoid statues appeared in a quiet corner of the Saint-Sophia of Kyiv conservation area, a 12-acre museum complex that is centered on the thousand-year-old Saint-Sophia Cathedral. Called “Shadows,” the clay-and-copper sculptures — each faceless and ghostly, with a torsolike form planted on a cylindrical base — had been made by Yuriy Myrko, a co-founder of GORN Ceramics in Kyiv for the annual Bouquet Kyiv Stage Festival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess
title: Sadie Sink Heads Back to School, This Time on Broadway
description: In “John Proctor Is the Villain,” the actress is among a group of students studying “The Crucible,” just as the #MeToo movement tears through their classroom.
content: For much of her high school career, Sadie Sink took her lessons inside an old lifeguard shack that had been converted into a schoolhouse for the child actors on the set of “Stranger Things.” When the cast wasn’t battling Demogorgons in a parallel dimension, “everyone was studying different things at the same time,” Sink told me recently of her experience in the shack. “It was chaos.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Oscars
description: What is your reaction to this year’s awards?
content: Did you watch the 97th annual Academy Awards on Sunday night?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Will Jarvis, Ian Stewart, Jessica Metzger and Ashley Southall
title: The Tariffs Are On, and Trump Suspends Ukraine Aid
description: Plus, women’s rugby gets a boost.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison, Eshe Nelson and Melissa Eddy
title: Trade War Sends a Shiver Through Global Markets
description: Wall Street has wiped out the gains made since President Trump’s election victory, as investors’ hopes of business-friendly policies have given way to fears over tariffs.
content: Stocks tumbled on Tuesday as President Trump’s broad tariffs against Canada, Mexico and China reverberated through global markets, intensifying investors’ concerns over the health of the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: James Harrison, Whose Antibodies Helped Millions, Dies at 88
description: James Harrison earned the nickname “The Man With the Golden Arm” because his blood had a rare antibody that may have helped more than two million babies in Australia.
content: James Harrison did not much care for needles. Whenever he donated plasma, he would look away as the tip went into his arm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan and Maya C. Miller
title: Veterans Are Caught Up in Trump’s and Musk’s Work Force Overhaul
description: Nearly 30 percent of civil service employees in the federal government are veterans. Democrats are highlighting their firings by taking some as guests to President Trump’s address on Tuesday.
content: Veterans, who make up a disproportionate share of federal employees, are feeling the brunt of the Trump administration’s rapid push to downsize the work force, generating discord in a reliable political base for Republicans.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Music Took Over This Year’s Oscars
description: On Popcast, a conversation about the smooth and bumpy ways that the Academy Awards incorporated music into its 97th annual ceremony on Sunday.
content: In seemingly every crevice of the 97th Academy Awards, there was music, or a reminder of it. Cynthia Erivo and Ariana Grande delivered one of their “Wicked” duets; Lisa, Doja Cat and Raye performed James Bond themes; Daniel Blumberg, a onetime indie-rock hero now on a second musical act, won best score; the host Conan O’Brien worked tunes into his stand-up bits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: It’s a Presidential Speech to Congress, but Not a State of the Union Address
description: Presidents generally deliver high-profile speeches to Congress shortly after their inauguration, and the distinction may make little difference.
content: President Trump’s address later on Tuesday to a joint session of Congress may look like a State of the Union speech and sound like a State of the Union speech, but it will not be one — at least not technically.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Ufberg
title: Hamilton Leithauser, an Indie-Rock Hero in a Very Fancy Room
description: For seven years, this Walkmen frontman has performed a residency at Cafe Carlyle. This year, he’s bringing along songs from a (louder) new solo album.
content: Even by Manhattan real estate standards, Café Carlyle is an intimate venue. The storied Upper East Side cabaret is just 988 square feet and seats 90 patrons, which means a performer can hear an audience member’s cutlery, not to mention their whispers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: America’s Flex
description: We cover President Trump’s new tariffs.
content: President Trump’s tariffs on Canada, Mexico and China took effect at midnight. By now, you’ve probably heard about the risks: higher prices, slower economic growth, a trade war. Trump acknowledges the potential for economic pain. Yet he signed off on the levies anyway — 25 percent for Canada and Mexico, another 10 percent for China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Duehren
title: Trump Administration Pushes to Slash I.R.S. Work Force in Half
description: Losing half of its employees would severely strap the I.R.S., meaning Americans may have to wait longer to receive tax refunds.
content: The Internal Revenue Service is preparing to shed as much as 50 percent of its staff, according to four people familiar with the matter, a significant cut that could jeopardize the agency’s ability to complete its basic mission of collecting taxes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Snyder and Luana Rigolli
title: Can a Finnish Sauna Improve Society?
description: Contemporary sweat baths reflect the country’s architectural past — and propose a future in which simple, sustainable buildings can still be sublime.
content: ON A WARM September afternoon in subarctic Finland, the architect Laura Mattila kneels in the grass beside a sauna that she and Mikko Merz, her 49-year-old partner in life and work, built eight years ago in the factory town turned artists’ colony of Fiskars, an hour’s drive west from Helsinki. Mattila, 40, doesn’t mention the near-perfect symmetry of the building’s two 135-square-foot volumes (one a changing room, the other the sauna), separated by an open void that frames the forest; or the construction’s elegant lock joints, folded like knuckles over the corners of its solid timber walls. Instead, she wants to discuss how the building works: Thin layers of linen packed between logs provide insulation; the stove’s residual heat and air circulation below dry the sauna between uses; gaps around the windows and doorjambs allow the timber to contract over time as it loses moisture. “If you think of a Finnish farmhouse, this is essentially how you build it: a log frame, an oven for baking and, once you’ve lived there for a while, you make another log frame and fill the gap between,” Mattila says. The project’s client, a 54-year-old conductor and violinist named Jan Söderblom, recalls asking the architects for “a combination of timeless and archaic.” So they gave him something virtually indistinguishable from the barns and saunas that Finns have built in their hardscrabble homeland for centuries.

At this uncommon entry to the growing lineup of Indian restaurants, whose name means “Madam Ji is getting married,” you only need to set aside several hours, even after the seasonal dessert in an elaborate simulated wedding feast menu ($65) has been cleared. (Seating is at 7:30 and 8 p.m. with an à la carte menu from 5 to 7 p.m.) Chipotle paneer, chicken tikka kebabs, truffle harvest kofta, coconut shrimp curry, slow-cooked goat royale and mithai, sweets offered as a “wedding favor” to take home in a gift bag, are served in rooms elaborately decorated according to symbolic wedding colors. The owner, Abishek Sharma, is a chef, restaurateur and caterer whose portfolio also includes the restaurants Swagat and Badshah.

content: When Martha S. Jones was a student at SUNY New Paltz, she took a course called “Black Sociology” with Prof. James Bowen. It was the mid-1970s, and the first Black studies department, founded at San Francisco State University at the height of 1960s student protests, was less than a decade old. As part of the first generation of African-descended young people to engage with Black culture and history in the college classroom, Jones was excited for all that Bowen’s class could offer.
